Award.AwardTitle: UCSD Education Studies Master Teaching Fellowship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Education Studies Program and the Physical Sciences Division of the University of California San Diego have established a Master Teacher Fellowship (MTF) program as part of their California Teach (CalTeach) Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program. This effort is a partnership with local high-needs school districts, mentor teachers, and local community colleges.

The intellectual merit is realized through the professional development offered to 42 local STEM teachers to serve as mentors and education leaders in high-needa school districts. Throughout the academic school year, Fellows participate in targeted online courses to further develop specific content and pedagogical skills. During the summer, Fellows join UCSD faculty for institutes in either mathematics or science instructional topics. UCSD has also established a Master Teacher in Residence program that recruits an MTF to join the university faculty each year, engaging them in teaching university coursework and supervising Noyce Scholars.

Expectation for Broader Impacts result from the project's further understanding of four vital components of learning and expertise development for teachers: the importance of mentorship, expertise development through experience, social networks, and blended learning. Finally, by enhancing the quality of mentorship that UCSD prospective teachers in the STEM fields receive, the project helps support the recruitment of highly qualified teachers in high need schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: The UCSD Education Studies Master Teaching Fellowship (MTF)

The UCSD Education Studies Master Teaching Fellowship (MTF) supported the leadership development of 40 math and science classroom teachers from across San Diego County. The goal of the program was to allow classroom teachers to develop leadership skills in curriculum and mentoring. The UCSD Master Teaching Fellows took over 80 content specific courses in topics such as differentiated instruction, GATE instruction, educational technology, and assessment. In addition to taking courses, our MTF teachers attended intensive workshops to learn implementation techniques in the Common Core State Standards of Mathematics (CCSS) and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). These activities provided our Fellows with a professional knowledge foundation to support changes at their school sites.

Through the UCSD MTF program, we developed a three-week online mentoring course for all the MTF teachers. The course, which continues to serve teachers who want to learn more about professional mentoring, provided the basis for supporting the MTF teacher in guiding new prospective teachers in their classroom. Through the program over 400 prospective teachers (at both the undergraduate and graduate levels) were mentored and guided as they worked in local high-needs classrooms with MTF teachers acting as cooperating teachers, co-teachers, and site-based mentors. 

Participants in the program reported feeling more confident to engage in leadership activities at the school and district levels as they gained knowledge and insights into curriculum and state policy. Beyond the self-reports of increased confidence, 40% of our MTF teachers have taken on additional leadership roles within their schools and districts, with 25% of these teachers serving as Teachers on Special Assignment (TOSA) at the district level in the areas of curriculum mentoring, technology integration coaching, and induction program support providers. 

We established an online professional network consisting of both the MTF teachers and our Noyce Teacher Scholars. This network represents many of the local school districts and has 80 active participants. Through the online portal, the participants engage in professional conversations about learning opportunities, curriculum and technology supports, and how to address changes in instructional standards. Each post to this online community receives an average of 50 views. MTF teachers and Noyce Scholars remain connected through the online community, often coming together for professional growth opportunities. The blending of these two communities, Master Teaching Fellows and Teacher Scholars, has been so successful that this distinction between the groups does not exist within the networked community. 

In terms of intellectual merits, the MTF program further builds understanding of four vital components of learning and expertise development: the importance of mentorship, expertise development through experience, social networks, and blended learning. Through ongoing professional learning in a professional network, our MTF teachers have increased their own teaching expertise and gained new skills in professional mentoring. While many reported a preference for face-to-face interactions, the blended environment of the online networked community has been viewed as a support to engage in higher level professional growth. 

The program’s broader impacts include a large cohort of experienced teachers to support and further the broader learning goals of students within San Diego schools. This goal has seen the formation of a core cohort of cooperating teachers to interact with pre-service teachers from UC San Diego as well as other local programs. By the end of the MTF program, our mentors have interacted with over 400 prospective new teachers. Their work as cooperating teachers continues with successive cohorts of new teachers.
